entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud : Cybersecurity, Compliance and Data Protection
entry.content:
(Jana Subramanian serves as the APJ Principal Cybersecurity and Compliance Advisor, handling strategic customer engagements across the APJ region, and is recognized as a Fellow of Information Privacy (FIP) by the International Association of Privacy Professionals (IAPP). In this capacity, Jana supports strategic customer engagements on topics including cybersecurity, data privacy, multi‑cloud security integration architecture, contractual assurance, audit, and compliance.)

Introduction

Organizations moving critical workloads to SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) are rightly focused on security, compliance, and governance. These are non-negotiable topics, especially for those in regulated industries. Customers need to know how SAP Business Data Cloud addresses data residency, secure transmission, encryption, access control, audit logs, secure connections among other security aspects.

This blog post provides a comprehensive FAQ, compiled from the most common questions we encounter in security reviews and compliance workshops. We will break down how BDC secures data throughout its lifecycle, from locking it to a specific region to extending data governance across Datasphere, SAC, and Databricks. This FAQ is designed to give security architects, compliance officers, and solution owners the clarity needed to understand how BDC meets stringent cybersecurity requirements.

Core Principles Guiding Security and Compliance in SAP Business Data Cloud

The robust security and compliance posture of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) is grounded in a set of foundational architectural principles that guide its design, provisioning, and operation:

  1. Data Gravity: In SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), analytics and services are deployed as close as possible to the data’s physical location, minimizing unnecessary data movement. SAP Datasphere functions as the central governed hub, enabling SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and Databricks to access governed datasets via live connections or zero-copy sharing. This architecture reduces latency, lowers data transfer costs, mitigates security exposure, and ensures data remains consistent and compliant with governance policies.
  2. Zero‑Copy: Within the BDC ecosystem, governed data is consumed by downstream tools (e.g., SAC (Live Connection) , Databricks) without creating additional physical copies. Through mechanisms like Delta Sharing, BDC ensures datasets remain in their governed location, enhancing data consistency while minimizing the compliance risk of unmanaged replication. (Note: This applies primarily post‑ingestion; initial ingestion from source systems may still involve physical replication.)
  3. Single Source of Truth (SSOT): Data Products in the BDC Catalog unify data from SAP and non‑SAP systems into a trusted, governed layer enriched with metadata, glossary terms, and KPIs. All consumers—SAC, Databricks, and other connected services—reference these governed Data Products to ensure consistent semantics across the enterprise.
  4. Security by Design: Security is embedded throughout the BDC lifecycle—from secure development and configuration to continuous operation. Role‑Based Access Control (RBAC), Data Access Controls (DAC), encryption, and secure integrations are built‑in, ensuring protection is not an afterthought but part of the platform’s design.
  5. Data Localization by Design: At provisioning, customers select a specific data center region, and SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) provisions and operates customer data–hosting components exclusively in that region. Certain dependent SAP Cloud services may be delivered from multiple regions depending on services selected, but these do not store or process customer data. All customer data, including backups and resiliency, DR resources, remains within the selected region unless otherwise contractually agreed.
  6. Least Privilege Access: Role Based Access Control (RBAC)  and Data Access Control (DAC) ensure users and applications are granted the minimal access necessary for their functions. This principle is enforced through scoped roles (e.g., BD Administrator, Catalog Admin, DW Modeler) and row‑level security controls in preparation spaces.
  7. Separation of Duties: BDC supports segregation of duties through distinct roles and space separation. Preparation spaces (for data engineering) are separated from application spaces (for data consumption), ensuring no single role can both create and consume sensitive datasets without governance oversight.
  8. Tamper-Proof Audit Logs: SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) maintains comprehensive audit logs capturing security-relevant activities, including role assignments, configuration changes, and Catalog administration events. Access to these logs is restricted to authorized administrators with explicitly granted privileges. While SAP does not describe these logs as “tamper-proof,” they are protected against unauthorized alteration or deletion, and retention is managed in accordance with compliance and audit requirements to ensure traceability and accountability.
  9. Service Continuity by Design: BDC incorporates redundancy, multi-AZ of dependent services deployment, and service resiliency measures to ensure high availability and operational resilience. SAP provides service‑level agreements (SLAs) for availability and recovery as part of its Security Measures for Cloud Services.

What are the considerations for selecting a region when configuring SAP Business Data Cloud to meet regulatory and residency requirements?

  • When provisioning SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) and associated solutions—such as SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and SAP Databricks—customers typically deploy in a single cloud region (subject to BDC service availability in that region) to meet data-residency, compliance, and performance objectives. SAP offers BDC in selected global regions (e.g., EU10, JP10, US10 as current examples), with specific service availability varying by region and hyperscaler location.
  • Customers choose the region at tenant provisioning (via SAP for Me or the applicable SAP provisioning workflow), usually based on regulatory requirements and latency needs. The selected region defines where customer data is stored, processed, and backed up. After provisioning, the region cannot be changed by simple configuration; relocating to another region requires a managed migration or re-provisioning.
  • To support residency, customer data—including backups and DR resources—remains within the selected region. Certain dependent SAP Cloud services may operate from multiple regions depending on the services used but do not store or process customer data. While co-locating BDC, Datasphere, SAC, and connected analytics/AI services in the same region is best practice for compliance and performance.

How does the shared security responsibility model apply to SAP Business Data Cloud?

  • In SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), security follows the shared security responsibility model. This means that SAP, as the Cloud Service Provider (CSP), is responsible for securing the underlying platform and infrastructure, while customers are responsible for managing security at the application, data, and user access levels. This clear separation helps prevent security gaps and ensures a strong end‑to‑end security posture.
  • SAP’s responsibilities include securing the core infrastructure of BDC and related service components (SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Databricks) —covering virtual infrastructure – Compute, Network, Storage —often operated through hyperscaler IaaS providers such as AWS, Microsoft Azure, or Google Cloud. SAP also manages platform availability, redundancy, encryption (at rest and in transit), and secure integration methods such as Delta Sharing, SAP Cloud Connector, and IP allowlisting. SAP provides built‑in identity and access controls for its own services, along with platform logging and audit reporting to demonstrate compliance with global standards.
  • Customers are responsible for securing their own tenant environment within BDC. This includes configuring secure connections from source systems, managing user roles and permissions, ensuring regulatory compliance  and applying least privilege access principles. Customers must also manage user lifecycle processes (onboarding/offboarding) and, where needed, apply additional security measures like anonymization or masking before replicating sensitive data. The shared model underscores that cloud security is a collaborative process—SAP delivers a secure platform, but customer diligence is equally critical in achieving a robust security posture.

 

Security Domain

SAP Responsibility (Cloud Service Provider)

Customer Responsibility

Cloud Infrastructure Security

Manages virtual access to Hyperscaler Virtual Infrastructure, Securing Cloud Accounts and Management. Hyperscaler handle physical data centre security.

Not applicable (managed by SAP and hyperscalers).

Network Infrastructure

Secures the underlying cloud network, including segregation, provider sub-account, access control, DNS, network routing, and platform segmentation.

Configures network access controls or IP allow listing for customer-managed connections.

Operating System

Manages the security of the operating systems running the BDC platform components, including container and cloud components security

Not applicable (managed by SAP).

Database Engine

Secures the database engines (e.g., SAP HANA Cloud) that store BDC data and metadata.

Manages database user access, roles, and data access controls within the database.

Platform Services

Secures BDC platform services (e.g., BDC Cockpit, Datasphere core, SAC core, Databricks runtime).

Configures and manages application-level settings, integrations, and data within these services.

Application Code

Develops and maintains secure application code for BDC components and intelligent applications.

Manages custom code or extensions developed by the customer within the BDC environment.

Data at Rest Encryption

Provides default encryption for data at rest using SAP-managed keys.

Manages customer-controlled encryption keys (CCEK) if opted for (such as SAP Datasphere)

Data in Transit Encryption

Ensures secure communication protocols (TLS/SSL) for data flowing within and to BDC.

Ensures secure connectivity from source systems to BDC (e.g .SDA, DP Agent, API)

User Access Management

Provides the Identity Authentication Service (IAS) and underlying authentication mechanisms.

Manages user creation, roles, permissions, and lifecycle within the BDC tenant. Enforces SSO/MFA.

Data Governance

Provides tools and capabilities for metadata management, lineage, and cataloging.

Defines and enforces data governance policies, data quality rules, and data product ownership.

Compliance & Audit Reports

Maintains platform-level certifications (ISO, SOC, GDPR) and provides audit reports.

Ensures internal use of BDC complies with industry/local regulations; consumes SAP's audit reports.

Data Residency

Offers provisioning in specific regions and enforces logical isolation.

Chooses the appropriate region for provisioning to fulfill data residency needs.

Incident Response

Manages security incidents at the platform and infrastructure level.

Manages security incidents related to customer data, applications, and user access.

How is data secured as it moves between source systems and SAP Business Data Cloud (Datasphere, SAC, Databricks)?

  • Data moving between source systems and SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) is protected through end-to-end encryption and strong authentication mechanisms. All connections—whether to SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), or SAP Databricks—use TLS-encrypted channels (minimum TLS 1.2) to prevent interception, with unencrypted connections explicitly rejected. For integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition, the ABAP Push Replication Service (APRS) is used for optimized, secure data movement. Calls from BDC to S/4HANA are authenticated using technical communication users with scoped authorizations, while mutual TLS with client certificates secures communication from S/4HANA to BDC.
  • BDC also supports additional safeguards, including Delta Sharing for governed, zero-copy data exchange; secure connectors and data agents for integration pipelines; centralized Connection Management; and IP allowlisting to ensure that only trusted networks and systems can exchange data.
  • Together, these measures ensure that data movement across the landscape remains confidential, authenticated, and compliant with applicable security and regulatory requirements.

What is Zero‑Copy Data Sharing and how does it enhance security and efficiency?

  • Zero-Copy Data Sharing in SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) enables datasets to be accessed in real time without creating additional physical copies. After the initial controlled replication into SAP Datasphere, services such as SAP Analytics Cloud (via Live Connection), SAP Databricks, or external platforms (via Delta Sharing) work directly on the authoritative governed dataset, eliminating redundant replications.
  • From a security perspective, each additional data copy increases the attack surface, compliance complexity, and risk of data sprawl. Zero-Copy sharing mitigates these risks by keeping data in a single managed location where governance, access controls, and audit policies are consistently enforced.
  • From an efficiency perspective, this approach reduces storage costs, maintains real-time consistency across consumers, and streamlines data lifecycle management, retention, and auditing—delivering faster insights without compromising control.

How does SAP BDC ensure secure integration with third-party data sources?

  • SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) secures integration with third-party data sources through a multi-layered approach combining secure connectivity, encryption, identity management, and fine-grained access controls.
  • Connectivity is established using trusted mechanisms such as the Data Provisioning Agent (DP Agent) and Smart Data Access (SDA), which enable secure connections to on-premise or cloud-based third-party systems via HTTPS and adapter-based integration. IP allowlisting is supported to restrict access to approved network ranges, ensuring that only trusted systems can connect to the BDC environment.
  • Authentication is enforced through enterprise-grade identity federation using X.509 certificates, OAuth 2.0, Single Sign-On (SSO), and Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA), with integration to the customer’s Identity Provider (IdP) for centralized access governance. Once data is ingested, Data Access Controls (DAC) in SAP Datasphere allow administrators to apply row-level security, user attribute-based filtering, and role-based permissions. All data—whether from SAP or non-SAP sources—is encrypted at rest and in transit.
  • Under the shared responsibility model, SAP secures the platform and integration tooling, while customers are responsible for configuring secure connectors, validating the security posture of external data sources, and ensuring compliance with applicable regulatory and privacy requirements. This design ensures that third-party integrations are secure, governed, and compliant by default.

How does SAP Business Data Cloud manage user authentication?

  • Default Authentication: Users are created manually or via CSV import. A welcome email with an activation link sets their initial password (optional if SSO is enabled).
  • SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS): Recommended for all BDC components to enable a shared authentication mechanism across the suite.
  • SAML Single Sign‑On (SSO): Customers can delegate authentication to their own SAML Identity Provider. SAML attributes (name, email, functional area) map to BDC user profiles and refresh at each login.
  • OAuth 2.0: Supports secure access for third‑party applications to SAP Datasphere within the BDC suite.

How is user authorization managed in SAP Business Data Cloud?

  • SAP Business Data Cloud manages user authorization through a structured roles and privileges framework. Roles group together specific privileges, which define the tasks a user can perform (e.g., manage data packages, configure governance) and the data they can access. Permissions—such as Create, Read, Update, Delete, Execute, Maintain, Share, and Manage—determine the exact level of access within each privilege.
  • BDC includes predefined standard roles (e.g., BD Administrator, BD Viewer, Catalog Administrator, Catalog User) that align with common responsibilities. Administrators can also create custom roles tailored to business needs, assigning precise permissions at the object level. Roles are assigned during user creation or import, and users can be activated, deactivated, or deleted as needed.
  • In SAP Datasphere, scoped roles (DW Integrator, DW Modeler, DW Consumer) manage access to specific spaces (Ingestion, Preparation, App). Fine‑grained row‑level security is enforced through Data Access Controls. All role changes and user activities are captured in audit logs, providing transparency and supporting compliance monitoring.

What are the mechanisms for user authorization and access control within SAP BDC?

  • SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) ensures secure user authorization through a layered system of roles, privileges, and data access controls. At the core of this system is SAP Datasphere, which uses “spaces” as governance boundaries. Only users assigned to a space can access the data and artifacts (such as tables, views, and models) within it. Within each space, security roles are assigned to users to define what actions they can perform in the web interface, while separate database users are defined for backend access and diagnostics.
  • For fine-grained access, BDC uses Data Access Controls (DAC) to enforce row-level security. DACs restrict data visibility based on user attributes (e.g., email or logon ID), mapped to specific data values (such as region or department). Even if users have access to a dataset, DAC ensures they only see the rows they are authorized to view. This is especially important for regulatory compliance, multi-tenant scenarios, and sensitive data segregation.
  • While DACs are highly effective when data is shared outside the space (e.g., to another space or external system), they may be bypassed within the originating space. Therefore, SAP recommends applying DACs as early as possible after data ingestion, wrapping source tables in views and using DAC-protected views for all downstream access. This strategy supports both security and performance, ensuring sensitive data is consistently protected throughout its lifecycle.

What are the encryption standards for data at rest in SAP BDC components (Datasphere, SAC, Databricks)?

All SAP Business Data Cloud components encrypt customer data, metadata, logs, and backups at rest to protect information even if underlying storage is compromised. Encryption uses strong standards (typically AES‑256) with keys managed via SAP or the underlying hyperscaler KMS.

  • SAP Datasphere: Runtime data in SAP HANA, data lake, and BW Bridge is encrypted with customer‑specific encryption keys. Metadata and configuration artifacts are stored in a shared database, encrypted with keys managed by SAP.
  • SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC): Data replicated into the SAC HANA database is encrypted at rest in line with SAP’s strong encryption‑at‑rest policies.
  • SAP Databricks: As an SAP‑managed Databricks runtime, encryption at rest applies to managed services, workspace storage, and clusters. Customers can enable customer‑managed keys (for control plane data, workspace storage, and cluster volumes) and use cloud KMS for storage encryption.

How is data encrypted in transit within SAP BDC and its connected systems?

SAP Business Data Cloud encrypts all data in transit using strong, industry‑standard protocols to protect against interception or tampering during transmission.

  • Within BDC and SAP Services: All communication between BDC components (including Datasphere, SAC) and connected SAP services is encrypted using TLS 1.2 or higher. Unencrypted connections (e.g., JDBC/ODBC to SAP HANA) are explicitly rejected. Web UI, CLI, and API access are also protected by TLS/SSL.
  • Advanced Event Mesh & Messaging: Events and messages exchanged via SAP’s event mesh are encrypted by default. Supported messaging protocols use TLS 1.2 or 1.3, with non‑encrypted protocols disabled by default.
  • SAP Databricks Integration: Data sent to Databricks clusters is encrypted in transit. This encryption‑in‑transit policy aligns with SAP’s global security framework, ensuring sensitive data is protected from unauthorized access or modification during transmission. Encryption is enabled by default across all components, with hyperscaler KMS integration ensuring secure key management and alignment with compliance requirements.

Does SAP Datasphere support Customer‑Controlled Encryption Keys (CCEK)?

  • Yes. SAP Datasphere encrypts all data, metadata, logs, and backups at rest using customer‑specific encryption keys. By default, each database—SAP Datasphere runtime, SAP HANA data lake, and SAP BW Bridge—is encrypted with a single customer‑specific key managed by SAP. Metadata and configuration information (such as design‑time artifacts, tenant settings, runtime metadata, schedules, roles, and Data Marketplace descriptions) are stored in a shared database, also encrypted with a dedicated key.
  • For customers requiring direct control over encryption keys, SAP Datasphere supports Customer‑Controlled Encryption Keys (CCEK) through SAP Key Management Service (KMS). With CCEK, customers provide their own key, which SAP uses to encrypt the database. Once enabled, CCEK cannot be reverted to SAP‑managed keys, and the key ID cannot be changed.

If the CCEK is disabled or deleted in the customer’s KMS, the SAP HANA Cloud database—and therefore the Datasphere runtime—becomes inaccessible until the key is restored. Customers should review key requirements and regional availability in the SAP HANA Cloud Administration Guide before enabling CCEK, as key management directly impacts database availability.

Customer Controlled Encryption Key 

What activities are logged in SAP Business Data Cloud?

SAP Business Data Cloud maintains comprehensive audit logging to ensure transparency, accountability, and compliance. Logged activities include:

  • Object and configuration changes — modifications to BDC assets, system settings, roles, and permissions.
  • Access control updates — grants, revocations, and changes to user privileges.
  • Catalog activities — metadata updates, asset publishing, glossary changes.
  • Role assignments — additions, removals, or updates to user roles.

User access events — logins, logouts, and database analysis user actions (captured in ANALYSIS_AUDIT_LOG for diagnostic purposes). Logs are available via the Security > Activities page to users with the appropriate privileges (e.g., BD Administrator). Deletion rights are restricted to authorized roles.

What tools are available for system landscape monitoring and connection testing in SAP BDC?

  • SAP Business Data Cloud provides the System Landscape page for monitoring formations and testing system connectivity. Users with BD Administrator or BD Viewer roles can view all formations, including associated SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Databricks, and LoB systems (e.g., SAP S/4HANA Cloud).
  • From this page, users can navigate directly to tenant URLs and run connection tests for SAP S/4 systems. Connection tests confirm if a system is operational, report errors when disconnected, or provide diagnostic messages when status is indeterminate—supporting quick troubleshooting with SAP Support.
  • While BD Administrators and Viewers can monitor systems, only the BDC Owner has permissions in SAP for Me to perform core provisioning or configuration changes, ensuring controlled system management.

Does data always remain in the source system, or is it copied to SAP BDC?

In SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), data does not always remain in the source system. While BDC emphasizes principles like data gravity and zero-copy data sharing to reduce data movement, it requires an initial, controlled replication of data into SAP Datasphere, which forms the foundational dataset for unified analytics and governance.

  • Initial Replication: Data from SAP and non-SAP sources is replicated once into SAP Datasphere—not in a continuous or uncontrolled manner. This enables centralized data modeling, governance, and flexible tiering (object, disk-based, in-memory) within a secure environment.
  • Zero-Copy Sharing: After replication, BDC enables real-time zero-copy access using technologies like Delta Sharing, allowing services like SAP Databricks or external consumers to use the data without creating new physical copies. This preserves consistency and performance.
  • Data Products: Curated and governed datasets—called Data Products—are stored across SAP Datasphere and SAP HANA Cloud Data Lake, supporting zero-copy access for tools like SAP Databricks and downstream apps.

This architecture strikes a balance between centralized control and distributed consumption, reducing data sprawl, improving security, and avoiding the inefficiencies of traditional, multi-copy ETL pipelines.

What is the process for data replication and its security implications in SAP BDC?

  • In SAP Business Data Cloud, data replication is a controlled process that brings data from SAP and non-SAP sources into SAP Datasphere to support analytics and AI. It begins with secure integration (e.g., using DP Agent or APRS), followed by an initial load and delta updates to keep data current. The replicated data is stored in protected Datasphere spaces like Ingestion, Preparation, and App, where it can be modeled and linked to tools like SAP Analytics Cloud.
  • From a security perspective, all data is encrypted in transit and at rest, using TLS/SSL and customer-specific encryption keys. Access is role-based, and row-level security (via Data Access Controls) ensures users only see the data they’re allowed to. The region where BDC is provisioned defines data residency, and customers must monitor replication jobs for consistency and compliance.

What are SAP Business Data Cloud Formations, and how do they enhance security and integration?

SAP Business Data Cloud Formations are logical groupings of SAP systems that automate and secure integration across components like SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Databricks, and Line-of-Business systems (e.g., SAP S/4HANA). Managed through SAP for Me, formations streamline connectivity, configuration, and data flow within a defined business scenario.

They enhance security and integration by:

  • Automating system integration, reducing manual configuration errors.
  • Structuring access and data flows through grouped components relevant to each use case.
  • Enabling application provisioning (e.g., intelligent apps and data packages) only through valid, predefined formations.
  • Providing centralized monitoring via the System Landscape page for connectivity health.
  • Allowing controlled inclusion/exclusion of systems to manage access and interdependencies.
  • Supporting multi-tenant landscapes with isolated formations for development, testing, and production.

In short, formations provide a secure and scalable integration backbone for SAP BDC ecosystems.

How do formations support data governance policies and architectural best practices?

  • SAP Business Data Cloud Formations play a key role in enforcing data governance by grouping related systems under a single, unified structure. They connect SAP systems like Datasphere, Analytics Cloud, and Databricks into one landscape, making it easier to manage metadata, user roles, and access control across tools. Assets from connected systems are automatically included in the catalog, where they can be discovered, classified, and governed. Formations also support compliance by enforcing policies such as regional provisioning and audit logging, ensuring consistent enforcement of data residency, privacy, and access policies.
  • From an architecture perspective, formations streamline integration and promote best practices by reducing manual configuration and simplifying the data landscape. They enable zero-copy data sharing (e.g., between Datasphere and Databricks), which enhances performance and avoids unnecessary duplication. They also support modular reuse of intelligent applications and data products, making the architecture more scalable, secure, and efficient for analytics and AI scenarios.

What are the recommendations to maximize security posture and compliance within the SAP BDC Environment

To fully leverage the security and compliance capabilities of SAP Business Data Cloud, organizations should adopt a proactive and collaborative approach, recognizing their responsibilities within the shared security model.

Deeply Understand the Shared Responsibility Model:

  • Organizations must thoroughly comprehend the division of security responsibilities between SAP and themselves. This understanding is foundational for allocating internal resources effectively, identifying potential security gaps in their domain, and ensuring that all necessary controls are implemented and maintained.

Implement Strong Identity and Access Management (IAM) Practices:

  • Centralize identity management by configuring a single Identity Authentication Service (IAS) tenant for all BDC components.
  • Enforce Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for all users, especially administrators.
  • Apply the principle of least privilege rigorously: assign users only the roles and permissions absolutely necessary for their job functions. Regularly review and adjust these assignments.
  • Align user lifecycle management processes (onboarding, role changes, off-boarding) with BDC's user management capabilities to ensure timely access provisioning and de-provisioning.

Proactively Manage Data Access Controls (DACs)

  • Design and implement DACs in SAP Datasphere as early as possible in the data flow, ideally upon ingestion, to enforce row-level security
  • Consistently use protected views for all downstream consumption and modeling to ensure that data access restrictions are always applied
  • Regularly review and update the permissions entities that feed DACs to reflect changes in user roles, organizational structure, or data sensitivity.

Strategically Choose Cloud  Regions:

  • Select the provisioning region for BDC components carefully to comply with all applicable data residency laws and internal organizational policies.
  • Understand the implications of SAP's "EU Access-compliant" stance for specific regulatory needs.

Ensure Secure Data Integration from Source Systems:

  • Utilize SAP's recommended secure connectors and agents (e.g., DP Agent, Cloud Connector) for all data integration points.
  • Implement IP allowlisting where possible to restrict network access to BDC to only authorized sources.
  • For on-premises or private cloud source systems, ensure the SAP Cloud Connector is securely configured and maintained, including proper certificate management. If native data masking is not available for specific sensitive data, implement custom filtering or anonymization at the source system before data replication into BDC.

Leverage Logging and Monitoring for Proactive Security:

  • Enable audit logs for SAP Datasphere spaces, especially when handling personal data, and configure appropriate retention periods. Regularly review system landscape monitoring dashboards and connectivity test results to quickly identify and address potential issues

Stay Informed and Engaged:

  • Regularly consult SAP's Trust Center, Security Guides, and SAP Notes for the latest security updates, best practices, and compliance certifications. Engage with SAP support and community forums to address specific security concerns and optimize configurations.

Conclusion

SAP Business Data Cloud delivers a comprehensive security and compliance framework built on principles like zero-copy data sharing, least-privilege access, encryption by default, and governance-driven integration. By combining SAP’s platform-level safeguards with customer-driven controls under the shared responsibility model, organizations can protect sensitive data throughout its lifecycle while meeting stringent regulatory and residency requirements. When paired with best-practice IAM, proactive monitoring, and secure data integration, BDC enables enterprises to unlock the full potential of governed analytics and AI without compromising trust or compliance.

References:

  1. SAP Business Data Cloud
  2. Modernizing SAP BW with SAP Business Data Cloud
  3. SAP Datasphere – Security Guide
  4. Administering SAP Business Data Cloud
  5. Securing Data Journey with SAP Business Data Cloud

entry.title: Simplify abap2xlsx: Convention Over Configuration for ABAP Excel Exports
entry.content:
Streamline Your Data Export Experience with a Simplified abap2xlsx Interface

Fellow ABAP developers! I'm excited to share an enhancement to the popular abap2xlsx framework that addresses a common pain point: the complexity of setting up Excel exports and handling nested data structures.

The Real Challenge We Face

How many times have you:

  • Spent hours configuring abap2xlsx settings for a simple export?
  • Manually written code to flatten hierarchical ABAP structures?
  • Repeated the same boilerplate setup code across multiple reports?
  • Struggled with converting nested internal tables into Excel-friendly flat structures?

While the vanilla abap2xlsx library is powerful and supports multiple formats, it requires extensive configuration and manual work for complex scenarios.

Introducing the Simplified Dynamic Export Add-on

The abap2xlsx-dynamic-export add-on transforms your export experience by providing:

🎯 Convention Over Configuration

  • Sensible defaults: Works out-of-the-box with minimal configuration
  • Simple API: One method call for most use cases
  • Override when needed: Customize only the options you actually want to change

🔄 Automatic Hierarchical Data Flattening

The system automatically processes nested structures using RTTS-based type analysis, converting complex hierarchical data into flat Excel tables while preserving relationships through intelligent NODE column generation.

🧠 Smart Type Analysis with Caching

  • RTTS-based analysis: Automatically discovers your data structure
  • Performance caching: Analyzes types once, reuses results
  • Memory management: Built-in monitoring and limits

Key Advantages Over Direct abap2xlsx Usage

 

Aspect Direct abap2xlsxDynamic Export Add-on
Setup ComplexityExtensive configuration requiredWorks with minimal setup
Hierarchical DataManual flattening code neededAutomatic RTTS-based flattening
Boilerplate CodeRepetitive setup across projectsReusable, consistent interface
Type DiscoveryManual field catalog creationAutomatic structure analysis
TestingManual test setupBuilt-in dependency injection for testing

Simple Usage Examples

Before (Direct abap2xlsx)

" Traditional approach - lots of setup code
DATA: lo_excel TYPE REF TO zcl_excel,
      lo_worksheet TYPE REF TO zcl_excel_worksheet,
      lo_writer TYPE REF TO zif_excel_writer,
      lt_field_catalog TYPE zexcel_t_fieldcatalog,
      ls_table_settings TYPE zexcel_s_table_settings.

" Manual configuration...
lo_excel = NEW #( ).
lo_worksheet = lo_excel->get_active_worksheet( ).
" ... many more lines of setup code

After (Dynamic Export Add-on)

" Simplified approach - convention over configuration
DATA: lo_exporter TYPE REF TO zcl_excel_dynamic_table.

lo_exporter = NEW #( ).
GET REFERENCE OF your_data INTO DATA(lo_data).
DATA(lv_excel) = lo_exporter->export_to_xlsx(
  io_data = lo_data
  iv_title = 'My Export'
).

Automatic Hierarchical Flattening

The add-on automatically handles complex nested structures that would require significant manual coding with vanilla abap2xlsx.

Real-World Impact

This add-on has proven valuable for:

  • Rapid prototyping: Get exports working quickly without configuration overhead
  • Consistent interfaces: Standardized approach across development teams
  • Complex data structures: Automatic handling of organizational hierarchies, product catalogs, and financial reporting trees
  • Maintenance reduction: Less boilerplate code to maintain

Built for Production

Unlike many community add-ons, this enhancement includes comprehensive test coverage and follows SOLID principles with dependency injection for reliable production use.

Call for Community Collaboration

This project represents a step toward making ABAP Excel exports more developer-friendly, but it can be even better with your input:

🔍 We Need Your Feedback:

  • What configuration scenarios are still too complex?
  • Are there hierarchical data patterns not yet supported?
  • What additional convenience features would help your workflow?

🤝 Contribution Opportunities:

  • Performance optimizations for large datasets
  • Additional convenience methods for common scenarios
  • Enhanced field mapping capabilities
  • Integration examples with existing frameworks

🧪 Testing & Validation:

  • Test with your real-world data structures
  • Report edge cases or configuration challenges
  • Share success stories and simplified workflows

Repository & Documentation

  • GitHub: kartefact/abap2xlsx-dynamic-export
  • Base Framework: abap2xlsx/abap2xlsx
  • Documentation: kartefact.github.io/abap2xlsx-docs
  • License: Open source - contribute freely!

Join the Discussion

I'm particularly interested in hearing about:

  1. Your current abap2xlsx setup pain points
  2. Complex data structures you're working with
  3. Configuration scenarios that could be simplified further
  4. Integration patterns with existing applications

Let's collaborate to make ABAP Excel exports more accessible and maintainable for everyone!

entry.title: Re: location and country/region columns missing on the UDF
entry.content:
Hi @user116 

The issue you are facing occurs because the UDF export are designed to only include fields that are classified as Basic User Information. Please note, fields like Location and Country or Region are often categorized as Extended User Information and thus are not included in the export by default.

Here are considerations to evaluate:

Map the extended Location and Country/Region fields into custom fields defined as Basic User Information.

Run the HRIS Sync job to populate these mapped fields. If you carried out recent changes, a full data model sync might be required to reflect the updates.

Ensure the fields are included in the data model sections exported by UDF. Confirm if the fields you have are standard or custom MDF objects. Please note that standard fields might require inclusion in your logic.

Schedule your job filters and confirm role-based permissions allow visibility of these fields during export.

After taking these steps, the Location and Country or Region values should appear correctly in your UDF export.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

3328525 - Employee Profile fields are not showing in UDF

3227711 - Showing "null" on second row header on UDF

2509740 - Second Manager Column is Missing in the Employee Export or UDF

entry.title: Re: Credit Control Area to be made optional on Business P...
entry.content:
Simply activating the FSCM credit-management business functions isn’t enough to surface the Credit Control Area field on your Business Partner (BP). You must also wire up the BP role and Card-Builder block in customizing.

Follow these steps:

Confirm you have these active in your system (via SFW5):

  • FIN_FSCM_CCD (Central Credit Management)
  • FIN_FSCM_CLM (Credit Limit Management, if used)

Without these, no credit-management data segments exist at all.

In SPRO → Financial Supply Chain Management → Credit Management → Integration with AR and SD:

  • Define Credit Control Areas
  • Assign Controlling Area to Credit Control Area
  • Assign Credit Control Area to Credit Segment
  • Maintain Credit Segment (UKM_CSEG table)

Make sure your company code’s controlling area is linked to a valid Credit Control Area, and that the Credit Control Area is assigned to a Credit Segment.

Open Fiori: Manage Business Partner Customizing (transaction code BUPT). Expand Credit Management → Credit Segment Data. Locate your BP Role (e.g. FLCU00 or the role you use for customers). Tick the Building Block UKM000 (or your custom Credit-Segment block).

In the BP transaction, add or verify the Customer Company Code role (FLCU01). Add (or confirm you already have) the Credit Management role (UKM000) and save. Once UKM000 is in the Roles tab and your block is active in customizing, you’ll see a Credit Segment section—complete with Credit Control Area, Credit Limit, etc.

entry.title: Income Tax Depreciation for Fixed Assets in SAP S/4 HANA (India Specific)
entry.content:
Introduction: 

Income Tax Depreciation India

Depreciation under the Income Tax Act is a deduction allowed for the reduction in the real value of a tangible or intangible asset used by a taxpayer.

Depreciation is defined as a reduction in the value of the asset due to wear and tear of the asset. People claim the deduction of depreciation only for accounting or for the purpose of taxation.

Difference between Book Depreciation & Tax Depreciation.

Book depreciation can be described as the amount registered in a company’s general ledger accounts. Book depreciation is always reported on the specific company’s financial statements.

Tax depreciation is the amount specified in the company’s income tax returns. 

The major difference between book depreciation and tax depreciation is timing. It includes the timing of when the price of an asset will reflect as depreciation expenditure on the company’s financial statement against depreciation expenditure on the organization's income tax return. Therefore, the depreciation expenditure will remain different in each year. However, the total of all years’ depreciation expenditure for any asset is expected to add up the same total. The organization needs to maintain depreciation records for financial statement depreciation. The organization should also need to maintain depreciation records for the tax return depreciation.

Tax depreciation is calculated for the purpose of income tax. Book depreciation is prepared in accordance with the matching concept. In other words, to prepare book depreciation the revenue and expenditures produced must be recognized and registered for a similar accounting period. The organization needs to maintain two kinds of records for depreciation namely for financial reporting purpose and income tax purposes.

Depreciation under Income Tax Act

Section 32 of the Income Tax Act 1961 talks about depreciation.

Income Tax Act of 1961 allows the depreciation of tangible assets and intangible assets. In the case of a tangible asset, we can claim the deduction against building, plant, and machinery. In the case of an intangible asset, we can claim a deduction against the patents, trademark, copyright, license, franchise or any other business or commercial right of similar nature. We can claim the deduction on depreciation on those assets which have been used by the assessee for the purpose of business or profession during the previous year.

If any asset which has been used for less than 180 days then 50% of depreciation is allowable in that year.

For Financial Year (April - March):

  • Asset which has been put to use till 2nd October, 100% depreciation will be charged
  • Asset which has been put to use after 3rd October, 50 % of depreciation rate will be charged.

Block of Assets

Depreciation is calculated on the WDV of a Block of assets. Block of assets is a group of assets falling within a class of assets comprising of:

Tangible assets, being building, machinery, plant or furniture.

Intangible assets, being know how, patents, copyrights, trade-marks, licenses, franchises or any other business or commercial rights of similar nature.

The block of assets is classified further depending on the similar use, life of the asset and nature of the asset.

Written down value method (Block wise)

Every year the book value of the asset decreases and depreciation of the asset is computed on the book value of the asset. The written down value (WDV) method is the best way to calculate the depreciation of the asset because the depreciation amount goes on decreasing with time. 

WDV under the Income Tax Act means:

Where the asset is acquired in the previous year, the actual cost of the asset shall be treated as WDV.

Where the asset is acquired in an earlier year, the WDV shall be equal to the actual cost incurred less depreciation actually allowed under the Act.

Additional depreciation under the Income Tax Act

The Income Tax Act only permits the written down value method. As per the Additional depreciation method, you can get the deduction only on those assets which have been used in the business or profession. However, an assessee can get the deduction only when assets are used in the year in which it was purchased.

If an asset has been used for less than 180 days then additional depreciation is allowed at 50% of the rate of additional depreciation.  

Who is non-eligible for the additional depreciation

Additional depreciation can not be claimed on plants and machinery which has been used outside India, before being installed in India. 

You cannot claim the deduction on those plants and machinery which have been installed in the office premises or in residential accommodation. 

Depreciation will be computed as follows:

Name of asset

Block 1

Block 2

Block 3

 

Machine – 15%

Furniture – 10%

Car -15%

Opening Value

0

0

0

Add- Purchases (>or = 180 days) Purchase (<180 days)

500000+40000

20000

300000

Less- Sold during the year

0

0

0

Closing value of block before depreciation

540000

20000

300000

Depreciation

78000

2000

22500

(500000*15% + 40000*15%*1/2)

(20000*10%)

(300000*15%*1/2)

Closing WDV after depreciation

462000

18000

277500

 

Configuration in SAP S/4 HANA:

  1. Business Function FIN_LOC_CI_8 should be activated in SAP. If not then activate the same. (SFW5)

  2. Depreciation Area 15 to be created. 

    Financial Accounting - Asset Accounting - General Valuation - Depreciation Area - Define Depreciation Area

     


    Here, area does not post should be ticket to avoid accounting entry creation, as ITD is only used for reporting and not for accounting.

  3. Add India Specific Tab added in the asset master tab specific layout, to get India specific tab activated in the Asset Master.

    Financial Accounting - Asset Accounting - Master Data - Screen Layout - Specify Tab Layout for Asset Master Record



  4. Depreciation area to be assigned to Asset class, each Asset class should be assigned to depreciation area 15, to get the ITD activated for the specific asset class.
  5. Block key field to be kept as mandatory in asset master. This is an optional step, if the business wants that the block in the asset master should be mandatory then this activity can be done.

    Financial Accounting - Asset Accounting - Master Data - Screen Layout - Define Screen Layout for Asset Master Data



  6. Asset Block Key Creation, this can be done via upload tool as well (J1INBLK).
    Financial Accounting - Asset Accounting - Master Data - Country-/Region-Specific Functions - India - Maintain Asset Block Details

 

After all the steps are done, block keys can be mapped in the master and the testing can be done.

Below are the list of t-code which is required for income tax depreciation.

S.No.T-codeDescription
1AS01  Asset Creation 
2AS02  Asset Change (Assign Block key) 
3J1INBLK Update Asset block key using excel file
4J1INBLKTOAST  Assign block to existing asset using excel file 
5J1INBLKOWDV  Assign Opening WDV to Asset block 
6J1INBLKADJST  Adjustment in Opening WDV of Asset Block 
7J1INBLKTRNS  Update asset transaction at block level 
8J1IDISPBLK  Display transaction details at Asset level 
9J1IDEPCALPOST  Income Tax Depreciation calculation report &Closing WDV Update 

The file format which SAP supports is .csv, below is the screenshot of the file format.

J1INBLK - To upload Asset block keys

J1INBLKTOAST - Assign block to existing asset using excel file 

Below is the list of manual activities which should be done on each server.

S.No.Manual (Cutover) Activities
1Asset master with block key
2Assigning opening WDV to asset block
3Adjustment of opening WDV with block key
4Update asset transaction detail at block level

SAP Menu path "ZITD - Income Tax Depreciation for Fixed Assets" can also be created via SE43 for the users ease.

Thank you for reading, and happy automating! 

 

Regards,

Tanya Srivastava

entry.title: Re: No actual line items were selected Message no. KB420
entry.content:
Even with identical selection variants and authorizations, you’ll often see two different behaviors when KSB1 finds no data:

  • Production (PRD): KSB1 stops at the selection screen and issues “No actual line items were selected – Message KB420.
  • Test (QAS/DEV): KSB1 proceeds to print an empty ALV grid (no error).

This discrepancy almost always comes down to ALV‐layout and variant differences, not authorizations. Here’s what to check—and how to harmonize both systems.


ALV Layout Must Contain Document Number
SAP Note 2445603 changed KSB1 so that if your default ALV layout includes the field BELNR (Document Number), the program takes an alternate code path: it builds the grid (even if no data) and suppresses KB420. If your layout does not include BELNR, KSB1 throws KB420 immediately.

In your Test system you’re (perhaps inadvertently) using a layout with BELNR, so you get a blank grid. b) In Production, your default layout omits BELNR, so you get the KB420 error.
To fix this, Run KSB1 → click Change Layout (the gear icon) → Choose Layout, Select your “Default” layout (or create a new one called e.g. Z_KSB1_EMPTY), in Displayed Fields, add Document Number (BELNR) and save. in Variant → Save as Default so that this layout is tied to your selection variant. Now even in PRD, KSB1 will show an empty grid instead of KB420.

Ensure the Same Variant/Layout Transported
Double‐check that the exact variant (with its layout assignment) you use in Test is also transported and set as default in Production:

  • In KSB1 → Variants → Display → compare the layout name and settings.
  • Use transaction RSEUVARA or SE38 report RS_VARIANT_CONTENTS to list the variant contents in both systems.
  • If there’s any mismatch, re‐transport the Test variant (and its layout) to Production.

Watch Out for Personal vs. Global Variants

  • Personal (user‐specific) variants in Test can differ from the global (all users) variant in Production.
  • Even if named the same, a personal variant isn’t the same object as a global one.
  • Be sure you’re running the Global variant in both environments, or transport your personal variant to Production as a global variant.

entry.title: Introducing VORTEX - Your UI5 SFTP Viewer/Manager in SAP BTP CF
entry.content:
Introduction:

This is a SFTP Viewer/Editor built in UI5 - I named it,  VORTEX.

Why did I think that we need something like VORTEX? 

I have witnessed first hand how teams download open source tools like fileZilla and WINSCP ( which by the way despite all their open source goodness have been branded as unsafe by some organization for internal use.) to explore file servers, view or edit files.

These could be Integration developers who try to access the file servers for troubleshooting or these could be functionals who would like to view the files for auditing purpose or verification or for any other reason.

Now coming to the Why!

1) It's not okay to share credentials - sometimes common credentials with team members only for them to store it locally in the FileZilla or WinSCP repo. This introduces unacceptable risk!

2) There is no logging so as to who tried to access which file or edited what?

3) Sometimes people leave the organization but they still have your remote SFTP server cred right? Again a risk!

4) There is no trail of any kind to track unauthorized changes to a file.

5) If the team members access these SFTP servers for example from their own desktop what about the firewall? Do you request a specific firewall rule just so that a team member can access the file server from their local desktop?

6) Private Keys! Some sftp servers need a private key for authentication, like bank SFTP servers. How do you connect to them if you have to from your desktop? Do you ask for the private key from the security team? (Don't request that now, there is high chance they wont share it. They are private for a reason.)

7) Some third party SFTP servers are only accessible from whitelisted IP's, for example you may have multiple connections from SAP CI to such SFTP servers and SAP CI / CF IP's have been whitelisted by the third party.

If you have multiple SFTP servers to connect to , credential management is a nightmare and because of multiple reasons above it's sometimes not possible to have a holistic centralized and controlled access.

 

Solution:  

This is where VORTEX comes in. I wanted to learn UI5 but couldn't find anything interesting that would drive me to learn it. Then I got this idea about VORTEX. I thought why not. And here we are 1 week later.

VORTEX is a tool build using SAP BAS, UI5, which connects with SAP CI using my state of the art custom API's  which leverage Connectivity service for accessing cloud connector, data stores, JSCH sessions, leveraging existing virtual host on your cloud connector.

The architecture is pretty neat, I will add a diagram later but the app in SAP BTP CF , connects to SAP CI via a destination and SAP CI custom code does the rest.

Here is how it looks...

VORTEX will display all your SAP Integration Suite IFLOWS, and then allows you to pull SFTP connection details from these iflows, all at once , or selectively.

VORTEX then shows you the available connections with the relevant info

Connections blank at first

 

 Scanning

 After I do the "Scan All" We can see the pulled connections.

 Now you will see "Unique" connections here, I have a algorithm in place to determine the uniqueness of connections. If you have new iflows , you can just again come back to this tool and scan the new flows selectively or scan everything again. This wont edit / remove existing connections but will just add new connections in the list.

Now comes the interesting part!! Hmmm.. what If I need to connect to a SFTP server which doesn't have a filow in SAP CI??

Okay...You ask too much! Fine.... Just add a new connection manually!

VORTEX allows you to add new connections, Edit connections and Delete connections. (Delete button is on the extreme right)

 

Result!

 VORTEX will now allow you to make the connection to this SFTP server through SAP CI! But there is a condition, the credential or the private key should be already there in SAP CI Secure store / keystore for VORTEX to use. This guarantees that users DO NOT have access to any secure material.

Now comes the Fun part........Let's Connect!

Notice that connect column with a play button? That's what we use to connect to a particular connection!

And now we are connected! You can see all the files and folders and they have different icons depending on their type. 

 The navigation bar on top is full functionals, allows you to go back and forth between folders, delete folders and shows you the path too. since we are on root it shows "/"

Lets open a File? Okay

You can now see the file in a text editor that allows you to edit / save / view the file, nothing more.

If its a pdf file it opens in UI5 PDF Viewer.

 The salient Feature?

It connects to all 6 SFTP Connection types, Internet - Basic auth, Internet - Cert Auth, Cloud connector - Basic auth, Cloud connector - Cert auth, Internet - Dual and Internet - Cert auth

Everything is logged and tracked and logs can be seen in a log viewer utility. This logs each action from logging in , to reading a file content, to editing it, deleting it etc.

So..... Let me know what do you think. I am happy given this was my first UI5 product. Also The UI5 is just the tip of the iceberg. The real deal lies in the custom code I have built in SAP CI which enables this to work seamlessly and allows any I mean ANY thing even postman to read, edit files or do anything on the file servers.

Hello


in the request : you will have tag for the Individual material. 
For each fixed asset, System creates the indivudal material ( Check Fixed asset - Master data tab - Individual material Sub tab)

in the Acc Coding block - you will need to provide the individual material  (On UI of Supplier invoice , Item - Cost Distribution tab Account assginment type is IMAT - Individual material when you would want to post the invoice with reference to Asset) ( either UUID or Indivudal material ID in the subnode ProductID of IndividualMaterialKey.

For the ProductTypeCode ( the productTypeCode NOde under IndividualMaterialKey should be either 1 or 3. I am not sure about this but it can not be 2, 4 or 5. which anyway is optional So i think you can avoid filling that as well).

1 = Material
2 = Service
3 = Indivudal Product

entry.title: Re: Custom Task for new Hire to Complete on day 1
entry.content:
Hi @DavidSnider 

The sequential display of new hire tasks on the employee’s homepage can be achieved by leveraging custom tasks in SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding. Please note, these tasks are built on custom MDF objects and linked to your onboarding programs.

By configuring your onboarding program and business rules appropriately, you can ensure that only one onboarding task appears at a time and the next task only becomes visible after the employee completes the previous one. Employees see these tasks as to-do cards on their homepage, which guides them step-by-step through their first-day activities.

To set this up, create a custom MDF objects to define each task's content. Then add custom tasks linked to your MDFs into onboarding programs assigned to new hires. Follow up by using business rules or workflow logic to control task sequencing. Finally, set up notifications to alert the employees when new tasks are assigned to them.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Issue with Automatic Inspection plan assignment to in...
entry.content:
You’ve created two inspection plans (GC 1 for Vendor 1, GC 2 for Vendor 2) and maintained QIRs for both on the MPN material—so now the system should pick the correct plan automatically. Here’s how to confirm everything is wired up and troubleshoot if it still always picks GC 1.

Step-1 - go to QI03, enter your Material + Plant + Vendor + Info Record. On the General Data tab, check that Status = 02 (Released). Only released QIRs are used in automatic determination. On the Inspection Plan tab, confirm that Group Counter and Usage = 04 (Goods Receipt) exactly match your plan.

In SPRO > Quality Management → Quality Info Record → Activate Quality Info Record for Usage 04. Ensure “Inspection Plan Assignment” is active for the Usage you’re testing. If you have multiple usages, make sure Usage 04 (or your Z–Usage) is included.

Step-2
In MIGO, post a GR for a PO item sourced from Vendor 2. Note the Material Document number and immediately run QA03 (Display Inspection Lot). On the Inspection Lot header, check Inspection Plan → Group Counter. If you see GC 2, it’s working correctly. If you still see GC 1, proceed to Step 3.

Step-3
By default SAP uses this sequence when selecting a plan (SPRO path):

  • Quality Info Record (Material + Vendor + Plant + Usage)
  • Task List Group (from material master) + Usage + Plant
  • Plan with highest status and lowest group counter

To confirm your lot hit the QIR step, in QA02 go to Environment → Inspection Lot → Plan Assignment Trace (or use transaction QPM9), review which branch of the logic found the plan.
